Subject: Re: [neat] Genome compatibility and Euclidean distance

Hi Ken,

> First, thanks for your contributions.  You've been a great help in
> developing my understandings of NEAT.  (I hope that is a compliment).

Thanks. ego boosts always welcome :)

> Are you saying (in effect) that Lp Norms are a good collection of "distance"
> metrics for genomes?

I'm saying that the current compatibility scheme in NEAT is
effectively using the L1 norm (Manhattan distance), and I'm now
hypothesising that this is better than the L2 norm (Euclidean
distance). I don't recall this ever coming up so maybe Ken S went
through this thought process right back in the beginning of NEAT.

I must admit to not having much of a maths background so I had to look
up Lp norms - maybe there is a case for some other value of P? Such as
<1 or the number of genes.


> I think these may have value in roulette wheel application to allele pattern probabilities.

So you think there is some research into biological genetics that
could give us some answers?

Regards,

Colin.
